text: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by persistently elevated blood glucose levels due to defects in insulin secretion, insulin action, or both. Long-term hyperglycemia is associated with damage to various organs, particularly the eyes, kidneys, nerves, heart, and blood vessels.

text: There are two major types of diabetes mellitus. Type 1 diabetes results from autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells, leading to absolute insulin deficiency. Type 2 diabetes is characterized by insulin resistance combined with relative insulin deficiency and is more common than Type 1 diabetes.

text: Common symptoms of diabetes include polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, fatigue, unexplained weight loss, blurred vision, and slow wound healing. Type 2 diabetes may be asymptomatic in its early stages and is often detected through routine screening.

text: Diagnosis of diabetes is based on laboratory criteria such as fasting plasma glucose of 126 mg/dL or higher, HbA1c of 6.5 percent or higher, or a random plasma glucose of 200 mg/dL or higher in the presence of classic symptoms.

text: Chronic complications of diabetes are divided into microvascular and macrovascular complications. Microvascular complications include diabetic retinopathy, diabetic nephropathy, and diabetic neuropathy. Macrovascular complications include coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, and peripheral arterial disease.

text: Management of diabetes focuses on achieving glycemic control, preventing complications, and improving quality of life. Lifestyle modification is the cornerstone of management and includes dietary changes, regular physical activity, weight management, and smoking cessation.

text: Pharmacologic treatment for Type 2 diabetes often begins with metformin unless contraindicated. Other glucose-lowering agents may include sulfonylureas, DPP-4 inhibitors, GLP-1 receptor agonists, SGLT2 inhibitors, and insulin therapy when needed.

text: Insulin therapy is required for all patients with Type 1 diabetes and may be necessary for patients with Type 2 diabetes if adequate glycemic control is not achieved with oral or non-insulin injectable agents.

text: Regular monitoring of blood glucose levels and periodic assessment of HbA1c are essential components of diabetes management. Patients should also be routinely screened for complications such as eye disease, kidney disease, and cardiovascular risk factors.

text: Education and self-management support are critical aspects of diabetes care. Patients should be educated about medication adherence, recognition of hypoglycemia, sick-day management, and the importance of routine follow-up with healthcare providers.

text: Hypertension is a chronic medical condition defined by persistently elevated arterial blood pressure. It is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, stroke, chronic kidney disease, and premature mortality.

text: Blood pressure is classified based on systolic and diastolic values. Normal blood pressure is defined as systolic less than 120 mmHg and diastolic less than 80 mmHg. Stage 1 hypertension is defined as systolic blood pressure between 130–139 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure between 80–89 mmHg. Stage 2 hypertension is defined as systolic blood pressure of 140 mmHg or higher or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg or higher.

text: Primary (essential) hypertension accounts for the majority of cases and has no identifiable secondary cause. Secondary hypertension may result from renal disease, endocrine disorders, medications, or other underlying conditions.

text: Initial evaluation of hypertension includes confirmation of elevated blood pressure readings, assessment of cardiovascular risk factors, and evaluation for target organ damage such as left ventricular hypertrophy, chronic kidney disease, or retinopathy.

text: Lifestyle modification is recommended for all patients with hypertension. Key lifestyle interventions include dietary sodium reduction, adoption of a heart-healthy diet such as the DASH diet, regular physical activity, weight loss in overweight individuals, moderation of alcohol intake, and smoking cessation.

text: Pharmacologic treatment is recommended for patients with persistent hypertension despite lifestyle modification or those with high cardiovascular risk. First-line antihypertensive drug classes include thiazide diuretics, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors), angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and calcium channel blockers.
